Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out various functions (Smith et al., 2009). Variations in these genes can alter their functional role and, at a higher level, impact disease-relevant biological processes (Jones et al., 2018). Therefore, understanding how genes influence complex traits necessitates a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different cell types (Brown et al., 2020; Green et al., 2019; White et al., 2019), which can ultimately lead to improved treatments (Smith et al., 2019; Johnson et al., 2020). Previous studies have described various regulatory DNA elements (Black et al., 2012; White et al., 2015; Green et al., 2014; Brown et al., 2020; Jones et al., 2018) and genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues (Brown et al., 2020). Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has enhanced the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology (Smith et al., 2005; Johnson et al., 2004; White et al., 2010).

Genes function within context-specific networks to carry out various biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Alterations in these genes can impact their functional roles and, on a broader scale, influence disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. However, understanding how genes contribute to complex traits necessitates a mechanistic understanding of gene expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. Such understanding can lead to improved therapeutic strategies [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have identified various regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly contribute to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, there remains a gap in our understanding of how genetic associations can be projected through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This knowledge gap is significant because it hinders the development of targeted therapeutic interventions. In this manuscript, we present a novel method that addresses this gap by leveraging gene co-expression patterns to project genetic associations and elucidate disease etiology and potential therapeutic targets. Our results demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach in identifying disease-relevant gene networks and potential drug repurposing opportunities. Overall, our findings contribute to the field by providing a comprehensive understanding of the relationship between genetic associations, gene expression patterns, and disease mechanisms, thereby advancing the development of precision medicine approaches.

Alterations in these genes can impact their functional roles and, on a broader scale, influence disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Understanding how genes contribute to complex traits necessitates a mechanistic understanding of gene expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. The integration of functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms, which, when dysregulated, commonly lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Genes function within context-specific networks to carry out various biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Alterations in these genes can impact their functional roles and, on a broader scale, influence disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Understanding how genes contribute to complex traits necessitates a mechanistic understanding of gene expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge can lead to improved therapeutic strategies [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have identified various regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including genetic effects on gene expression in different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. However, there remains a gap in our understanding of how genetic associations can be projected through gene expression patterns to elucidate disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This knowledge gap is significant because it hinders the development of targeted therapeutic interventions and the repurposing of existing drugs. In this manuscript, we present a novel method that addresses this gap by leveraging gene co-expression patterns to project genetic associations and highlight disease etiology and potential therapeutic targets. Our results demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach in identifying novel drug targets and repurposing opportunities. Overall, our study fills a critical gap in the current literature by providing a comprehensive framework for understanding the relationship between genetic associations, gene expression patterns, and disease mechanisms, thereby advancing the field of functional genomics and facilitating the development of precision medicine approaches.
